problem_text:
We call a variety passable if there exists an unrefinable chain of its subvarieties which is well-ordered by inclusion. For example, every variety generated by its finite groups is passable — this is an easy consequence of (H. Neumann, Varieties of groups, Berlin et al., Springer, 1967, Chapter 5). Do there exist non-passable varieties of groups?
A. V. Kuznetsov
answer: Yes, there do (M. I. Anokhin, Moscow Univ. Math. Bull., 51, no. 1 (1996), 48–49).
